intro: Scandix hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy scabweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant has finely hairy leaves that are usually arranged in a basal rosette, and it produces small, dry fruits called schizocarps. Scandix hirsuta is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides, and it is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
